org.jtrim.concurrent

Interface TaskFuture<V>

  • Type Parameters:
    V - the type of the result of the asynchronous computation

    public interface TaskFuture<V>
    Represents the result and the current phase of execution of an asynchronous computation (usually submitted to a TaskExecutorService. The main feature of TaskFuture is that, other tasks may wait for the completion and the result of the task the TaskFuture represents. These waits can be done by the waitAndGet methods.

    Thread safety

    Implementations of this interface are required to be safely accessible from multiple threads concurrently except for the getTaskState() method.

    Synchronization transparency

    The methods of this interface are not required to be synchronization transparent.
    See Also:
    TaskExecutorService

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      TaskState getTaskState()
      Returns the current phase of execution of the asynchronous computation.
      V tryGetResult()
      Retrieves the result of the asynchronous computation if it already completed or returns null if it did not.
      V waitAndGet(CancellationToken cancelToken)
      Waits until the asynchronous computation terminates and returns the result of the computation or throws an OperationCanceledException, if this method is requested to be canceled.
      V waitAndGet(CancellationToken cancelToken, long timeout, java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit timeUnit)
      Waits until the asynchronous computation terminates or the specified timeout expires and returns the result of the computation or throws an OperationCanceledException, if this method is requested to be canceled.

    • Method Detail

      • getTaskState

        TaskState getTaskState()
        Returns the current phase of execution of the asynchronous computation. That is, if it has been started, currently running or terminated. There are three possible ways for an asynchronous computation to terminate: be canceled, throw an exception or complete normally.

        If the return value of this method defines that the computation has already terminated (i.e.: getTaskState.isDone() == true), subsequent waitAndGet methods will not block but return immediately (either by returning the tasks result of throwing an exception if it did not complete normally).

        Note that this method must be synchronization transparent.

        Returns:
        the current phase of execution of the asynchronous computation. This method never returns null.

      • tryGetResult

        V tryGetResult()
        Retrieves the result of the asynchronous computation if it already completed or returns null if it did not. This method always returns immediately and will not try to wait for the asynchronous computation to complete.

        In case getTaskState.isDone() == true prior to this call, this method will never fail to retrieve the result of the computation: It will either return the result of the computation or throw an exception if the computation did not complete normally.

        Returns:
        the result of the asynchronous computation if it already completed or null if it did not yet complete. Note that a return value of null may also means, that the asynchronous computation returned null.
        Throws:
        OperationCanceledException - thrown if the asynchronous computation has been canceled (and also terminated)
        TaskExecutionException - thrown if the asynchronous computation has already terminated by throwing an exception. The actual exception is the cause of this TaskExecutionException which is never null.

      • waitAndGet

        V waitAndGet(CancellationToken cancelToken)
        Waits until the asynchronous computation terminates and returns the result of the computation or throws an OperationCanceledException, if this method is requested to be canceled.

        In case getTaskState.isDone() == true prior to this call, this method will never fail to retrieve the result of the computation and will not block: It will either return the result of the computation or throw an exception if the computation did not complete normally.

        Parameters:
        cancelToken - the CancellationToken which can be used to signal that this method needs to stop waiting for the asynchronous task a terminate by throwing an OperationCanceledException
        Returns:
        the result of the asynchronous computation which can possibly be null
        Throws:
        OperationCanceledException - thrown if the asynchronous computation has been canceled (and also terminated) or this method was requested to stop waiting by the specified CancellationToken. Which of these events occurred can be detected by the result of the getTaskState() method.
        TaskExecutionException - thrown if the asynchronous computation has already terminated by throwing an exception. The actual exception is the cause of this TaskExecutionException which is never null.
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if the specified CancellationToken is null

      • waitAndGet

        V waitAndGet(CancellationToken cancelToken,
           long timeout,
           java.util.concurrent.TimeUnit timeUnit)
        Waits until the asynchronous computation terminates or the specified timeout expires and returns the result of the computation or throws an OperationCanceledException, if this method is requested to be canceled.

        In case getTaskState.isDone() == true prior to this call, this method will never fail to retrieve the result of the computation and will not block: It will either return the result of the computation or throw an exception if the computation did not complete normally.

        Parameters:
        cancelToken - the CancellationToken which can be used to signal that this method needs to stop waiting for the asynchronous task a terminate by throwing an OperationCanceledException
        timeout - the maximum time to wait for the result of the computation in the given timeout. This argument must be greater than or equal to zero.
        timeUnit - the time unit of the timeout argument. This argument cannot be null.
        Returns:
        the result of the asynchronous computation which can possibly be null
        Throws:
        OperationCanceledException - thrown if:
        • the asynchronous computation has been canceled (and also terminated) or
        • this method was requested to stop waiting by the specified CancellationToken or
        • the specified timeout elapsed without the asynchronous task terminating.
        Which of these events occurred can be detected by the result of the getTaskState() method and the cancelToken.isCanceled() method.
        TaskExecutionException - thrown if the asynchronous computation has already terminated by throwing an exception. The actual exception is the cause of this TaskExecutionException which is never null.
        java.lang.IllegalArgumentException - throw if the specified timeout value is less than zero
        java.lang.NullPointerException - thrown if any of the arguments is null
